ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Mixed lecture-seminar model.
virtual, live seminar

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Professor Calabresi's class provides such an insightful understanding of Constitutional law, its hard to know where to begin. Calabresi's knowledge is unmatched at Yale, and through the comparative perspective I truly garnered an understanding of what changes should occur in our system. This is one of the few courses that lives up to its title because you literally learn about everything in the domain of comparative constitutional law.

Learned a lot about the constitutional and judicial structures of other major countries. Learned about the many different judicial models around the world, as well as some of the history behind the current legal systems we see in the world today
I learnt a lot about comparative constitutional law in the US and in other G-20 countries.

One important insight I developed in this course is that constitutions in countries worldwide and the guarantees of liberty enshrined in them, absolute or qualified, did not emerge from a vacuum. Instead, each country's constitution tells the story of its political past.
learned about comparative constitutional law across the g-20 countries
I learned a great deal about comparative constitutionalism and learned how to compare different constitutional systems to better understand each system.
I learned about different constitutions around the world, focusing specifically on G20 countries and improved my legal analysis skills.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Professor Calabresi is one of the most wonderful professors I have ever encountered. Calabresi is extremely knowledgeable in the field of law and provides an incredible insight as to the academic dialogue surrounding key issues. He is the strength of this class. The reading material is not overbearing, however, Calabresi's casebook provides so much substance that you walk away feeling like you have learned the material of three classes combined. There are no weaknesses to this class. Calabresi is open to the opinions of students and always differentiates between his personal philosophy and facts, which is super helpful.

Overall, fantastic course. Prof. Calabresi is very knowledgeable and happy to talk with students outside of class. Perhaps the course tries covering a bit too much materials sometimes, to the point where certain interesting topics feel a bit rushed.

I think the main strengths of this course are Professor Calabresi's incredible wealth of knowledge on the topic. Since he wrote the textbook we use, he is able to go very in-depth into all of the concepts and cases we talk about. I also think this class is unique in that it's comparative in nature. A lot of the law classes at Yale are very US-centric, and while US cases probably take up 60% of the class, the other 40% is spent talking about cases in a whole host of other countries. I think one improvement could be to spend less time on Professor Calabresi's presentations during lectures (since they mostly go over the readings), and spend more time on discussion.

This course exposed students to constitutions and constitutional case law from other democracies, which we compared against the U.S. Constitution and several Supreme Court cases since the founding. At the end of the semester, I had a broader understanding of Constitutional law in both the United States and several G-20 democracies.

Professor Calabresi did a good job of keeping seminars busy over zoom in the sense that there was no awkward silence. He would cold call students which helped drive conversation and also have his own interpretations in addition to provided slides with background information on the topic.

Strengths: class discussions were very interesting, readings were useful for understanding material, and Professor Calabresi did a great job of summarizing lengthy and complex readings in class

Weaknesses: nothing that I can think of! It was a great class
The lecture component is super interesting and useful!

Professor Calabresi is engaged with his students and facilitates a lively debate in class. He covers a lot of legal issues in many countries, so the course can only go into so much depth on each, but you get a great breadth of information.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Overall, seminars do not work as well virtually as they do in person. But I think Prof. Calabresi did a good job balancing his lecturing and trying to involve students. I find that Prof. Calabresi calling on students who raised their hands was a better system than just telling people to talk (as other seminars do).
The PowerPoints were really helpful over zoom.
The class discussions worked well, I thought. The presentations were interesting, but I think if they were either shorter, or broken up into smaller components, student engagement could be higher.
The course was a mixture of lecturing by Professor Calabresi and discussion by the entire class. Overall, everyone was engaged each week as we all participated in class discussions.

The seminar could be long and exhausting because it was over zoom, but Professor Calabresi included slides in the beginning of each seminar to help provide further background information and as a base on which to jump off of for discussion. He also cold called students to keep the discussion moving instead of letting awkward silence sit over zoom.

Online learning worked well this semester in this course, and we were able to have very informative discussions as a group together despite the virtual format. It felt a lot like a normal seminar, so I have only positive things to say about the class!

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: ABSOLUTELY! If I had to chose one must take class at Yale, it would be this one! What an incredible opportunity to learn from such a knowledgeable individual who truly cares about his students and the class. It is rare that someone of Calabresi's stature is so humble, yet insightful in his classes. Even though the class was only once a week, I have learned so much in the topic of constitutional law, and I could not recommend this class enough.
Absolutely. Anyone interested in law, or even just interested in history, should try to take this course. Material was very interesting and Prof. Calabresi was engaging.

I would definitely recommend this course. I always walked away from class feeling like I had learned something new and worthwhile. The papers are manageable, but they do take a fair amount of time to research and write. Overall, I enjoyed the class a lot. If you're considering law school, I think it's worth taking.

Yes! If you're interested in constitutional law in different countries, take this course! You learnt a lot about different constitutional law concepts, and how they manifest in a wide variety of nations.
I would recommend this course to another student because the topics covered are fascinating but equally important.

If you enjoyed Constitutional Law and want to take more law classes, this is the next step in that path. great class if you love constitutional law and want to learn more about other countries and their legal systems

Yes, if you want to better understand not only the American Constitution, but the whole grouping of constitutional systems in which it exists. Although the class does have a decently heavy. workload (lots of readings on a weekly basis), it is very informative, interesting, and worth taking if you are interested in law.
Yes! The reading was overwhelming but the lectures - seminar format was great and the subject really interesting.
Yes, studying with Professor Calabresi has been a highlight of my time at Yale.
